awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Cybersecurity Big Data Research for Hacker Communities: A Topic and Language Modeling Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
It is estimated that cybercrime costs the global economy around $445 billion annually, particularly due to intellectual property theft and financial fraud using stolen consumer data. Incidents of large-scale hacking and data theft occur regularly, with many cyberattacks resulting in theft of sensitive personal information or intellectual property. Cybersecurity will remain a critical problem for the foreseeable future, necessitating more research on a large, diverse, covert and evolving international hacker community. Computer science and social science researchers face non-trivial challenges, such as the technical difficulties in data collection and analytics, the massive volume of data collection, the heterogeneity and covert nature of data elements, and the ability to comprehend common hacker terms and concepts across regions. In order to alleviate these challenges, this project has two research goals: 1) advance current capabilities for scalable identification, collection, and analysis of international hacker community contents, and 2) make contributions to the cybersecurity community by developing new big data techniques that could enable researchers to conduct analyses on hacker content and other related domains.  The impact of the project is made through the sharing and dissemination of our comprehensive hacker community data collection, advanced collection strategies, and innovative analytical approaches within the NSF Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace data science and other communities.

This project aims to develop a large, comprehensive and longitudinal testbed of all significant international online hacker community contents, including: forums, IRCs, underground economies, and other emerging hacker assets, for the cybersecurity and big data communities. The analytical approaches mainly aim to address the large-scale international hacker community content analysis for proactive cyber threat intelligence (CTI). In order to analyze hacker contents, the project develops an innovative, holistic, and proactive CTI framework encompassing Cross-Lingual Knowledge Transfer to alleviate the language barrier, Nonparametric Supervised Topic Modeling to profile key hacker assets, and Scalable Dynamic Topic Modeling to inform emerging threat detection. UA's National Security Agency-designated Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense, Research, and Operations, NSF Scholarship-for-Service (SFS) Cyber-Corps, and top-ranked Master's in Cybersecurity programs position the project for synergy with teaching and research. Techniques developed in this project not only advance CTI knowledge, but also deep transfer learning, deep generative modeling, supervised topic modeling, dynamic topic modeling, neural variational inference, and numerous other important domains. Results from this research will be disseminated through various academic and cybersecurity industry channels such as undergraduate and graduate curricula, IEEE Intelligence and Security Informatics conference, National Cyber-Forensics Training Alliance (NCFTA), The Society for the Policing of Cyberspace (POLCYB), and NSF CyberCorps SFS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Hacker communities, which commonly exist as web forums, Internet-Relay-Chat (IRC) channels, and underground economies, allow hackers to share cybercriminal assets such as hacking tools, malware source code, and hacking tutorials with one another. These contents pose a challenge to traditional cybersecurity researchers who may lack the technical proficiency to effectively document these items or interpret their value relative to the skill and ability of the participants. Many hacker communities make use of anti-crawling mechanisms to block collection efforts. Foreign language issues also arise due to hacker communities existing globally (e.g., Russian, Chinese, Iranian, etc.), presenting yet another barrier to research. Consequently, there is a critical need to advance existing capabilities to collect and analyze international hacker communities on a large scale for cybersecurity researchers and professionals, as well as criminologists studying various forms of malicious online behavior.

This project focused on four sets of research activities. First, we collected an extensive testbed of hacker-generated content from hacker forums, IRC channels, and underground economies. Novel data collection methods were developed to bypass anti-crawling measures such as CAPTCHA images. Second, we developed several automated methods for understanding multilingual hacker community contents based on cross-lingual knowledge transfer and domain adaptation to facilitate multilingual CTI analytics. In our benchmark evaluation, our proposed method outperformed the baseline methods by identifying more hacker assets and accommodating more languages. Third, we developed a novel framework for identifying key hacker assets (e.g., exploits, ransomware, stolen data dumps, etc.) from hacker communities using nonparametric supervised topic modeling. Our proposed framework systematically examines hacker-generated reviews of hacker assets to discover topics indicative of high-quality hacker assets. One type of key hacker asset we identified is the “Fully UnDetectable” malware, capable of bypassing malware detectors. We therefore expanded the scope of our research to develop data-driven methods to address the key hacker asset of “Fully UnDetectable” malware. Specifically, we developed and evaluated several state-of-the-art approaches for emulating adversarial malware attacks and enhancing malware detectors against adversarial attacks. Fourth, we developed a novel dynamic topic model capable of modeling temporal attributes of hacker community content to examine hacker discussion evolution and to assess what cybercriminal threats may be rising or declining based on changes in hacker discussions. Drawing upon neural variational inference, our proposed method not only outperformed the state-of-the-art baseline methods but also obtained important insights about emerging threats in hacker forums. One emerging threat from our analysis is the widespread circulation of PII leaked in prior data breaches, which can lead to identity theft, financial losses, and reputation damage. Such leaked PII can cause significant implications if paired with the publicly available PII on the surface web (e.g., people search engines, social media, public records, etc.). Accordingly, we expanded the scope of our research to address the emerging threat of leaked PII records circulating in the hacker community. Several novel deep learning techniques were developed for the assessment of individuals’ privacy risks across the Dark Web and the surface web.

The broader impacts of this project are four-fold. First, these research activities have resulted in over 30 peer-reviewed publications disseminated through major journal and conference outlets, such as IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence, IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, ACM Computing Surveys, ACM Transactions on Management Information Systems, Journal of Management Information Systems (JMIS), Management Information Systems Quarterly (MISQ), and IEEE Intelligence and Security Informatics (ISI). Second, key findings from our research activities were shared with a broad practitioner audience from NCFTA, POLCYB, US Secret Service, Canada Revenue Agency, and several other industries and law enforcement partners. Both NCFTA and POLCYB, deeply engaged with the broader cybersecurity practitioner communities, further disseminated recordings of our presentations to their practitioner partners. Third, outreach activities were conducted to engage with the larger AI and machine learning community. These activities helped build the community of AI for Cybersecurity, as well as provide larger visibility for our project activities. Examples include organizing conferences and workshops such as IEEE ISI, ACM KDD AI4Cyber Workshop, and ICDM Workshop on Machine Learning for Cybersecurity. Finally, selected data, analysis methods, and results were integrated into UA’s and UGA’s cybersecurity curriculums in three ways: UArizona's NSA-designated Center of Academic Education in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) courses, the online MS in Cybersecurity program, and UGA's undergraduate area of emphasis in Information Security. The project activities also provided research experience for UArizona's NSF CyberCorps Scholarship-for-Service (SFS) students and UGA's Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) students.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2024
Modified by: Hsinchun Chen

These contents pose a challenge to traditional cybersecurity researchers who may lack the technical proficiency to effectively document these items or interpret their value relative to the skill and ability of the participants.
